content.description: One of the best of its grade at the Draw. Great moves out a short roof with a maze of holds give way to more great moves pulling pockets up a face. A sloping, rocky landing makes the tall-ish finish that much more exciting.
content.protection: A pad (or three) and attentive spotter(s).
content.location: On the left side of The Egg is a small roof. This climbs out the left side of the roof into many pockets on the face.

content.description: Excellent. Begin at a right hand sidepull and a flat hueco. Climb past thin dishes and slopers to big holds above. Significantly harder in the sun.
content.location: A few yards right of the roof at the left end of the Killer Wall, climbing a wide pale streak.

content.description: Start left hand on an obvious incut crimp and right hand on a low shallow pocket. Bump right to and intermediate and then up to better holds to the top. It's a lot harder than it looks
content.location: This is the right most problem on the White Wall

content.description:
Nice problem on the right half of killer wall. This is probably easier if you're taller. One of the slopers is quite greasy but an alternate dyno beta allows you to skip it and makes it a fun problem nonetheless.

 ​youtube beta video​​​
content.location: Low start on two good pockets to the right of whip and the cross. Killer Wall #11 in Jason Henrie and Zak Farmer's the boulderingtopo.com eGuide. Move up and to the right staying left of the V0 jugs. Use the slopers crimps or sidepulls as you see fit to make a big move to a jug straight up.

content.description: The roof up and left from the Killer Wall: start on good holds and make a couple of very committing moves to reach the lip. The landing is more or less a loose rocky gully, try not to tumble all the way to the bottom of the Draw. Exciting!
content.location: Walk up and left around the edge of the Killer Wall and look for this short roof.

content.description: Starts on the big sidepull flake and immediately moves out right to a complex of small crimps in the black and tan streaks. Figure out a way to get established on the crimps and make a large move to a blocky jug followed by easy moves to the break.
content.location: The middle/right side of The White Wall. Shares the starting flake of Dishwasher.

content.description:
The traverse of the Pottery Wall. Start with a close two-finger pocket and dish near the right side of the wall. Powerful, precise and nearly footless moves on deep pockets reach some jugs in the tan rock. Push on with better holds through the tricky sequence of the second half to top out on the far left side of the wall. Holds above the middle row of pockets are off until the topout. 

  There is a start further to the right called Luke Cockstalker that requires a very long reach right off the bat and checks in around V10.
content.protection: A runway of pads is really nice, but one or two will do if you have an attentive spotter.
content.location: Traverse the Pottery Wall from right to left.

content.description: Start matched in the same large slopey undercling as Carne Cabeza and trend right instead of left for the first move. Continue up and right to large edge and easy top out.
content.location: Directly underneath the start of streetfighter on the right side of the pottery wall.

content.description: Located on the left side of White Wall. Climb up vertical face to the break, then start busting out the roof via the left trending rail. A long pull from the rail to a sloping crimp starts the fear lurking inside. 20 feet up with a heal hook and the sloping crimp, find a decent pinch out left near the lip of the overhang. Keep a good heal as long as possible! Climb smart to the top. Classic Priest Draw movement at a committing height.
content.protection: For the best Money Shot, protection isn't used.
content.location: Left side of the White Wall.

content.description: Long and sustained traverse across the pottery wall. This problem starts on the rightmost feature of the pottery wall. Perform a few tenuous moves to get into street fighter. finish the climb as for that problem. Pumpy.
content.location: The pottery wall is one of the walls closest to the main parking lot. From the main lot cross the draw to the northern side and continue to the right until you find the wall.

content.description: Start on good holds and follow the seam up through a cruxy move into the giant dish, then finish on good holds. Looks a bit stout until you find the hidden jugs.
content.location: About 10 feet left of Dishwasher on the White Wall is a prominent crack/seam feature. Climb it. Traverse or jump off.

content.description: Follow jugs leading up and slightly left.
content.location: Starts right of the pine tree, near a large block.

content.description: A series of small pockets to low-angle terrain.
content.location: Start below the pine tree in the middle of the wall.

content.description: This is the lowball traverse of the row of pockets on the Killer Wall. Stay on the lowest holds the whole way! The first hard sequence comes pretty quick, traversing under the start of The Whip and the Cross on greasy slopers and crimps. A few easy moves bring you to a bum-dragging undercling crux in the black rock. Finish with the easy problem on the far right.
content.protection: You could bring a pad for the crux maybe.
content.location: Killer Wall, traverse it left to right on the lowest holds.

content.description: prominent left-angling flake.
content.location: Leftmost route on Killer Wall proper.

content.description: Just right of the Yoker is another great V4. Long, secure moves out the roof lead to two pockets at the lip, followed by a baffling long reach to a jug on the face. The bad landing and high topout will keep you on your toes.
content.protection: A pad (or three) and attentive spotting.
content.location: On the roof on the left side of The Egg, this climbs out the right side of the roof to an obvious long reach on the face.

content.description: Start on the huge sidepull / undercling flake and go straight up crimps and slopers to chunky rock above. Very fun problem.
content.location: Toward the right end of the White Wall, look for the prominent undercling flake a few feet left of the black streaks. Get down by traversing right.

content.description: Start with matched hands in the large sloping undercling underneath the start of streetfighter. Paste a low foot and huck your left hand up to a good pocket and proceed up and slightly left to top out. Definitely a one-move wonder but a fun burly move nonetheless.
content.location: On the pottery wall, starting holds directly underneath the starting feature of streetfighter.

content.description: Just left of The Whip and the Cross. Start low on slightly slopey pockets and go straight up to a crux move off a nasty horseshoe crimp, then top out on jugs. Many awkward moves off weird and unpleasant holds make this an affair to remember.
content.location: Near the left end of the Killer Wall just to the left of The Whip and the Cross.

content.description:
Start with both hands underclinged and go left hand to the pocket above your head. Set a right heel and surf your right hand out to a pinch above and to the right. Throw to a big flat pocket with the left and do an easy topout.

Vimeo.com/59033857
content.location: On the pottery wall to the left of streetfighter by a few feet. Starts under the headwall.

content.description:
Within sight of the main parking area at the Draw are several limestone walls with an abundance of excellent problems, mostly vertical to slightly overhanging and in the V0-V5 range with a few steeper, harder lines scattered around. Left to right: 

The Egg: An egg-shaped wall of white limestone with two great V4 roof problems on the left and two much harder lines climbing into the vertical seam in the center. 

Killer Wall: A long band of multi-colored and well-featured stone peppered with large huecos, pockets and slopers. Contains some of the best non-roof climbs at the Draw, including The Whip and the Cross and a long, difficult traverse of the low row of pockets (The Killer Inside Me), along with a bunch of good moderate warmups. 

White Wall: A vertical-to-slightly-overhanging band of pale stone, unique in that it is relatively devoid of pockets and most problems instead use edges, slopers, seams and chunky blocks to reach a break about 12 feet up. There are a few great moderate problems here along with a couple of very difficult lines. White Riot, the 5.13 trad route recently featured in Climbing, climbs out the high roof above this wall. 

Pottery Wall: A funky, black-and-white striped cliff with a roof at the bottom climbing into a wavy wall above. There are many easier stand-start problems with very difficult low starts under the roof, but the main attraction here is Street Fighter, a cool traverse of the row of pockets running the length of the wall.
